summary: This is a Law360 news article from April 24, 2019, reporting that a Florida appeals court dismissed a lawsuit against Jeffrey Epstein filed by modeling agency MC2 Model & Talent LLC and its owner Jean-Luc Brunel due to improper service of process. The article also provides background on Epstein's criminal history, the non-prosecution agreement, and the allegations against Brunel.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The defendant in a lawsuit filed by a modeling agency. He successfully argued improper service of process, leading to the dismissal of the suit. The article details his criminal history and status as a registered sex offender.

persons.name: Jean-Luc Brunel
persons.role: Plaintiff / Owner of MC2 Model & Talent LLC
persons.context: Co-plaintiff who sued Epstein, claiming his notoriety cost the modeling agency business. He is linked to Epstein and accused of supplying him with underage girls. He attempted to serve Epstein at multiple addresses.

persons.name: Alexander Acosta
persons.role: Then-U.S. Attorney and current Labor Secretary
persons.context: Mentioned as a prosecutor who, along with others, violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by signing a nonprosecution agreement with Epstein without notifying his victims.

persons.name: Kevin Emas
persons.context: One of the judges who sat for the Florida Third District Court of Appeal panel that issued the ruling.

persons.name: Edwin A. Scales III
persons.context: One of the judges who sat for the Florida Third District Court of Appeal panel that issued the ruling.

persons.name: Norma S. Lindsey
persons.context: One of the judges who sat for the Florida Third District Court of Appeal panel that issued the ruling.

persons.name: Scott J. Link
persons.context: Represented Jeffrey Epstein in the appeals case, along with Kara Berard Rockenbach.

persons.name: Kara Berard Rockenbach
persons.context: Represented Jeffrey Epstein in the appeals case, along with Scott J. Link.

persons.name: Joe Titone
persons.context: Represented Jean-Luc Brunel and MC2 Model & Talent LLC in the lawsuit against Epstein.

connections.description: Brunel sued Epstein, claiming Epstein's notoriety hurt his modeling business. Brunel has also been linked to Epstein and accused of supplying him with underage girls.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, was a prosecutor who signed a nonprosecution agreement with Epstein, which a judge later ruled violated victims' rights.
Link, along with Kara Berard Rockenbach, represented Epstein in the appeals court case regarding the modeling agency lawsuit.
Rockenbach, along with Scott J. Link, represented Epstein in the appeals court case regarding the modeling agency lawsuit.
Titone represented Jean-Luc Brunel and his company MC2 in their lawsuit against Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Modeling Agency Lawsuit Filed
events.description: Jean-Luc Brunel and MC2 Model & Talent LLC sued Jeffrey Epstein in Miami, claiming his notoriety from sexual assault charges cost the agency business.

events.title: Epstein's Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty to felony charges involving solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution. He served 13 months in prison.

events.title: Trial Court Accepts Service
events.description: A trial court deemed service of the lawsuit on Epstein at his U.S. Virgin Islands business address as acceptable.

events.title: Appeals Court Dismisses Suit
events.description: Florida's Third District Court of Appeal ruled that Brunel and MC2 failed to properly serve Epstein at his primary residence and dismissed the lawsuit without prejudice.

events.title: Federal Judge Rules on Victims' Rights Violation
events.description: A Florida federal judge ruled that prosecutors, including Alexander Acosta, violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by signing a nonprosecution agreement with Epstein without notifying his victims.

locations: Little St. James, U.S. Virgin Islands
keyFacts: A Florida appeals court dismissed a lawsuit against Jeffrey Epstein filed by modeling agency owner Jean-Luc Brunel due to improper service of process; Epstein was not served at his primary residence on Little St. James island.
Jean-Luc Brunel has been linked to Epstein and accused by at least one victim of supplying Epstein with underage girls.

In February 2019, a federal judge ruled that prosecutors, including Alexander Acosta, violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by not notifying Epstein's alleged victims of a 2007 nonprosecution agreement.
Epstein pled guilty in 2007 to felony charges of soliciting prostitution and procuring minors for prostitution, serving 13 months in prison and becoming a registered sex offender.

The article references a Miami Herald report alleging dozens of victims claim Epstein lured teenage girls to his Palm Beach mansion for sexual acts, and that they have not had the opportunity to testify in court.
